intro: Rhus macrophylla, commonly known as the coast live oak, is a deciduous evergreen tree native to coastal regions of California and Baja California. It is characterized by its broad, leathery leaves that are typically 5–10 inches long and have a distinctive wavy margin. The tree produces small, yellowish flowers in clusters, followed by spherical, spiny fruits that contain one or two seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to mild, coastal climates with moderate rainfall. Rhus macrophylla plays an important ecological role, providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
